metadata.title: PointCNN: Convolution On X-Transformed Points
metadata.author: Yangyan Li, Rui Bu, Mingchao Sun, Wei Wu, Xinhan Di, Baoquan Chen
metadata.abstract: We present a simple and general framework for feature learning from point clouds. The key to the success of CNNs is the convolution operator that is capable of leveraging spatially-local correlation in data represented densely in grids (e.g. images). However, point clouds are irregular and unordered, thus directly convolving kernels against features associated with the points, will result in desertion of shape information and variance to point ordering. To address these problems, we propose to learn an X -transformation from the input points, to simultaneously promote two causes. The first is the weighting of the input features associated with the points, and the second is the permutation of the points into a latent and potentially canonical order. Element-wise product and sum operations of the typical convolution operator are subsequently applied on the X -transformed features. The proposed method is a generalization of typical CNNs to feature learning from point clouds, thus we call it PointCNN. Experiments show that PointCNN achieves on par or better performance than state-of-the-art methods on multiple challenging benchmark datasets and tasks.

highlights: Spatially-local correlation is a ubiquitous property of various types of data that is independent of the data representation
For data represented in point cloud form, which is irregular and unordered, the convolution operator is ill-suited for leveraging spatially-local correlation in the data
We summarize our 3D point cloud classification results on ModelNet40 and ScanNet in Table 1, and compare to several neural network methods designed for point clouds
We proposed PointCNN, which is a generalization of CNN into leveraging spatially-local correlation from data represented in point cloud

While X -Conv is empirically demonstrated to be effective in practice, a rigorous understanding of it, especially when being composited into a deep neural network, is still an open problem for future work
key_statements: Spatially-local correlation is a ubiquitous property of various types of data that is independent of the data representation

For data that is represented in regular domains, such as images, the convolution operator has been shown to be effective in exploiting that correlation as the key contributor to the success of CNNs on a variety of tasks [25]
For data represented in point cloud form, which is irregular and unordered, the convolution operator is ill-suited for leveraging spatially-local correlation in the data
We propose to randomly sample and shuffle the input points, such that both the neighboring point sets and order may differ from batch to batch
We summarize our 3D point cloud classification results on ModelNet40 and ScanNet in Table 1, and compare to several neural network methods designed for point clouds

As shown in Table 6, we summarize our running statistics based with the model for classification with batch size 16, 1024 input points on nVidia Tesla P100 GPU, in comparison with several other methods
We proposed PointCNN, which is a generalization of CNN into leveraging spatially-local correlation from data represented in point cloud

While X -Conv is empirically demonstrated to be effective in practice, a rigorous understanding of it, especially when being composited into a deep neural network, is still an open problem for future work
summary: Spatially-local correlation is a ubiquitous property of various types of data that is independent of the data representation.
Sparse data in irregular domains can be represented as graphs, or meshes, and a line of work have been proposed for feature learning from such representations [31, 55, 30].

Following the hierarchical construction of grid-based CNNs, we would like to apply X -Conv on F1 to obtain a higher level representation F2 = {(p2,i, f2,i) : f2,i 2 RC2 , i = 1, 2, ..., N2}, where {p2,i} is a set of representative points of
We denote a representative point in {p2,i} as p, the features with p as f and its K neighbors in {p1,i} as N, the X -Conv input for this specific p is S = { : pi 2 N}.
For an input point cloud without any additional features, i.e., F is empty, the first X -Conv layer uses only F .

The process of assembling a deep network with X -Conv layers highly resembles that of grid-based CNNs. Figure 4a depicts a simple PointCNN with two X -Conv layers that gradually transform the input points into fewer representation points, but each with richer features.
We propose PointCNN with denser connections (Figure 4b), where more representative points are kept in the X -Conv layers.

In the second X -Conv layer of PointCNN in Figure 4b, dilation rate D = 2 is used, all the four remaining representative points “see” the entire shape, and all of them are suitable for making predictions.
The global coordinates of the representative points matter, they are lifted into feature space RCg with M LPg(·) and concatenated into X -Conv for further processing by follow-up layers.
For MNIST data, PointCNN achieved comparable performance with other methods, indicating its effective learning of the digits’ shape information.

For CIFAR10 data, where there is mostly no “shape” information, PointCNN has to learn mostly from the spatially-local correlation in the RGB features, and it performed reasonably well on this task, though there is a large gap between

With the qualitative visualization and quantitative investigation, we conclude that though the “concentration” is far from reaching a point, the improvement is significant, and it explains the performance of PointCNN in feature learning.
We proposed PointCNN, which is a generalization of CNN into leveraging spatially-local correlation from data represented in point cloud.
The core of PointCNN is the X -Conv operator that weights and permutes input points and features before they are processed by a typical convolution.
We open source our code at https://github.com/yangyanli/PointCNN to encourage further development
headline: We present a simple and general framework for feature learning from point clouds
